ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Meniere's Disease
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss progressing to flat SNHL, and confirmed by ENT with eCochG.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Noise-Induced Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of significant factory and motorcycle noise exposure likely contributing to high-frequency thresholds and tinnitus pitch.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Severe Tinnitus Disorder
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Tinnitus causing severe distress (THI 76, TFI 88) and suicidal ideation, requiring psychiatric intervention.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing thresholds given report of sudden hearing loss and tinnitus.
To evaluate speech understanding and check for retrocochlear signs (asymmetry).
To assess middle ear function and acoustic reflexes.
To characterize tinnitus pitch, loudness, and maskability.
Follow-up to monitor progression of hearing loss.
Follow-up to assess changes in speech recognition.
Repeat testing to confirm absent reflexes.
Re-evaluation due to increased severity and distress.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation revealed mild-to-moderate SNHL with asymmetry (worse in right ear) and absent acoustic reflexes bilaterally. Tinnitus was tonal, high-pitched, and maskable. The patient reported vertigo and sudden hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Sloping mild to moderate SNHL. Left ear: Within normal limits to mild loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right SRT 30 dB HL, WRS 100% (or 70% at 50 dB). Left SRT 15 dB HL, WRS 92%.

tests.name: Tinnitus Assessment
tests.result_summary: Pitch match 6.5 kHz; Loudness match 12 dB SL; Residual inhibition 8 s; THI 32 (Mild).

tests.name: Immittance
tests.result_summary: Type A tympanometry bilateral; Acoustic reflexes absent bilaterally.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Patient returned one year later with diagnosis of Meniere's Disease. Vestibular symptoms resolved, but tinnitus distress became severe with suicidal ideation. Hearing in the right ear progressed to a flat moderately severe SNHL, while the left ear showed a low-frequency rising configuration.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Flat moderately severe SNHL (65-70 dB HL). Left ear: Moderate low-frequency loss rising to normal.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right SRT 65 dB HL, WRS 52% at 95 dB HL. Left SRT 25 dB HL, WRS 90% at 55 dB HL.

tests.name: Tinnitus Assessment
tests.result_summary: Pitch match 9 kHz; Loudness match 14 dB SL; Residual inhibition 12 s; THI 76 (Severe); TFI 88 (Severe).

tests.name: Immittance
tests.result_summary: Type A tympanometry bilateral; Acoustic reflexes absent bilaterally.

proposed_items: Immediate escort to emergency room for psychiatric monitoring
Custom silicone canal-style earplugs for noise protection
Fit with unilateral Receiver-in-Canal (RIC) hearing aid in the right ear
Sound therapy with high-pass filtered noise (automatic) and manual masker options (pink noise, ocean waves)
counseling_actions: Counseling on the relationship between Meniere's Disease, hearing loss, and tinnitus
Counseling on the importance of hearing protection during motorcycle riding and work
Explanation of sound therapy benefits and residual inhibition results
Coordination with mental health providers regarding suicide risk and depression

red_flags_present: Suicidal ideation with a specific plan
Unilateral tinnitus and asymmetric hearing loss

escalation.rationale_short: Patient expressed suicidal ideation with a plan during the interview, requiring immediate psychiatric safety monitoring.

follow_up_plan.timeline: 1 month, 3 months, then phone calls at 6 months and 1 year
follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor tinnitus distress, adjust amplification and sound therapy settings, and ensure psychiatric stability.

expected_outcome: Patient reported substantial benefit with the device at 1 month.
At 3 months, patient reported little to no tinnitus perception with the device in place.
At 1 year, hearing was stable and tinnitus was not present at the time of the appointment.
At second annual follow-up, no evidence of tinnitus disturbance was found on inventories.
